He began to present his views in private as he had opportunity, praying that some minister might feel their force and devote himself to their promulgation. But he could not 
                                                                           331
banish the conviction that he had a personal duty to perform in giving the warning. The words were ever recurring to his mind: "Go and tell it to the world; their blood will I require at thy hand." For nine years he waited, the burden still pressing upon his soul, until in 1831 he for the first time publicly gave the reasons of his faith.
